text: They treat you like a person, not an employee. That’s reflected in the benefits and how management approaches employees, no yelling and screaming about challenges, just collaboration and ideas. The office environment is very fun, and expansive (can only speak for Seattle). It is a very challenging company due to the pace and ingenuity around every corner, which is awesome. If you apply yourself, you’ll go somewhere. Yes, office politics exist, but generally, it’s a meritocracy.”

Great place to work at where employees are looked after and listened to.I found it was a safe environment where the management listened to any safety concerns brought up.Great work life balance where time off for me wasn't an issue as I have family living at long distances.

At the city it is the 80/20 rule. 80% are dead beats and 20% are doing good work. Many should be let go but have a union defending them. Over 19 years with water services I finally had enough. I would have more in my pension if I invested it on my own and with company matching. The best part is the 4 day or 3 day work week. But if you are motivated and a go getter and want to make lots of money this is not the place for you. It is for people with no motivation who want to survive only and not looking for better opportunities. Job security seems to be the motivation at the city.
cons: Mentally draining, nothing makes sense, just show up and do what you are told and you will be fine.

text: Union based.  Advancement is primarily based on senority and not how hard you work.  Vacation days are also allotted by senority; don't pick popular dates to take off. No political stress.  Do your job and you'll be fine.  Salary is high compared to private sector.  Great organization to work for.
pros: Salary, compressed work week, schedule, benefits

text: Suitable job for students and people looking part time work. This position does not get the benefits other government employees receive. Wage is not great either
Perfect work, life balance, supportive management , professional development opportunities are some of the reason I enjoy working at the City of Calgary

If you get into a good team, it's golden. If not, there can be very traumatizing, back-biting, dysfunctional behaviours to deal with from either bosses, coworkers or both. The policies for respectful workplace and the like, exist... the trouble is that in some groups, they are not enforced. There are sweetheart deals for some staff but not for others. It is stressful that some situations are not fair, makes you feel vulnerable and that is unproductive. Some mgmt should not be in their positions due to no education or life experience for the responsibility. They tend to hire leaders from within the ranks of staff and then don't require them to seek further education. If you get a leader who has integrity, cares and is true to his/her word, then you will thrive and enjoy your career. It's unfortunate, but the "good" leaders are few and far between. Just when you think you have the worst leader... and get a different job, you find out that this one is even worse. The benefits are ok, not super. I like that there's a pension. I have benefitted from working from home since the pandemic. The best thing is the ability to move around by applying for different positions. Hopefully, you can find something/someone to your liking. I am a technology worker, indoors, working 37.5 hours/wk. There are flexible work options and now Telework options.
pros: Telework/working from home, flexible work schedules, pension, stat hol
cons: Few good leaders/bosses. Weak union. Very weak HR dept.

text: It's a very clique environmet. they keep hiring lots of regulars for the elections wich leads to a very unwelcoming "team". The process taught during training were changed last min by the PDRO Wich also made me uncomfortable as the reason sited for the change was "too much cleaning and sanitizing". The city give a time frame for payment then completely changes it weeks later and blames the delays on Canada Post. All around a truly miserable expirience. If you worked an elections Canada elections and think this would be similar you would be wrong. Stick to elections work with standards consistently followed.
No strong leadership. People pay more attention to office politics.Good work-life balance.Passive-agressive attitude.Good benefits, defined benefit pension.

Too many managers and far too many promoted beyond their ability but no accountability. Just riding it out until they hit their full pension. Also, instead of solving tough problems the mgmt likes doing re-orgs.
pros: Working to better Calgary is fun
cons: Too many lazy people hiding from accountability

text: Good work life balance and benefits.  Lots of turn over in our department for years.  Re organization ongoing for the last 5 years. Same staff levels as 6 years ago with much more work to do. Not as enjoyable place to work as it was years ago.
cons: constant middle management changes, unhappy retirees, burn out good staff.

text: It's a nice place if you're looking for some job security but not too much advancement when it comes to career. I love the 4 day work week which gives more work/life balance.
The City of Calgary is a nice place to work.  Competitive salary, and reasonable work hours.  The union is a bit ridiculous and heavily favors the tenured.

Poor wage compared to real world. Pension is constantly increasing in cost and decreasing in value. Follow collective agreements, safety, code of conduct and policies when it suits them, otherwise they look the other way. Management has too many layers and considers the fundamental reason of existence (provide service to citizens) a nuisance to their “projects”.
pros: Compressed work week (if you can get it)
cons: Safety perceived, but not achieved. Zero management accountability

text: Everyone wants to work for the City but don't be fooled. They oversell the benefits but are not competitive at all. If they want to build a great City they should start with their own organization. There is very little diversity at non-elected senior levels. Policies are outdated and focus on controlling what can go wrong and giving the minimal required versus assuming the best in people. No paid sick days for the first 3 months, then only 90% pay if you are sick (even for exempt positions), low end of the scale for vacation and have to wait until the next calendar year to get your accrued vacation. Working from home is a non-starter because management doesn't trust that employees are working.Senior leaders think they are smarter than everyone else and give very little autonomy. You are told what to do--ideas, work, and policies flow from the top down. Managers and above think and say they are better than people below them doing the work. Leaders take no accountability. blame others, and look for mistakes to point out leading to low collaboration and fear.Processes and technology are out dated and instead of focusing on a great employee experience leaders and HR want to micromanage, assume you will take advantage of the system, and track everything you do with constant reminders that IT is tracking activity on computers.
pros: Work Life Balance, Little risk of being fired after probationary period
cons: No paid sick days for first 3 months, no vacation days within the first year, No autonomy., No flexibility, hierarchical, lead with fear

text: They say they care about their employees and they mean it. Very supportive group while I was there. I’m happy that I had the chance to work there - it was an excellent place to learn and grow as a professional.
pros: Excellent people, interesting work, very collaborative and a sense we are all on the same team
cons: None that I can think of.

text: Stay outta the drama. Politics. Gossip. Go to work. Do your job. Mind your business. Good jobs at the city. You sometimes work alone. Can do what you please as long as work is completed.
pros: 4 day work week. 9.5 hours. No micro managing.

text: Very toxic work environment. So many levels of unnecessary management. Reckless spending. Management clueless as to what was going on around them..

in my opinion, there are several ways can make a company developing successfully. First, the ower has to hire right person. all staff has to be honest, talent, and hard worker.   Secontly, the ower respect staff, pay staff fairlly. For daycare,the ower and all the teacher have to respect family and love all the children, especially, give the children excellent  traning and care.
pros: the ower can offer free lunch to staff that would make all of staff happy, but it is not very important.
cons: If the ower pay for it that is OK.

text: Good place.Lot to learn.DiversifiedInclusionSlow & steadyGovernment regulations and policies.Structured.Remote some times.Travel within the city.
So many options once you are employed Great benefits All supplies and uniforms providedInterview is by at least two peopleCheck Calgary.ca for Interview tips and Guidelines.

They treat you like a person, not an employee. That’s reflected in the benefits and how management approaches employees, no yelling and screaming about challenges, just collaboration and ideas. The office environment is very fun, and expansive (can only speak for Seattle). It is a very challenging company due to the pace and ingenuity around every corner, which is awesome. If you apply yourself, you’ll go somewhere. Yes, office politics exist, but generally, it’s a meritocracy.”

Benefits and pay are fair and there’s a health and wellness program. I enjoy the work as you can see direct positive impacts in the community. There are many layers of management with leads, coordinators, managers. It’s extremely stressful to have work constantly downloaded through attrition and departmental business changes. There’s a lack of accountability and change impact review as well as out of touch upper management.
Staff and Managers are supportive and understanding. It is a fast pace job with many departments and programs so, need to take time and meet people and learn about their positions.

Decent pay and work-life balance, but limited career advancement opportunities. Stigma of lazy environment. The farther from center the worse harassment and favoritism problems. Big words about commitment and values, but no second thought when it's time for lay offs. Satisfaction surveys are only collected in good times, and no exit polls for departing employees. Dysfunctional union that restricts flex work, caps salaries below market, and does not represent employee.
pros: Annual salary increase, decent pension plan.
cons: Questionable job security, no/weak bonuses, health & dental compensations not reviewed for ages, union spoiled many benefits.

text: Pleased to have the opertinity to apply myself, learm and grown, meet knew challanges and build solid working relationships with skilled staff. Provid building ownership a level of compliance through contractor inspection and compliance checks. Understand the importance of keeping all facility dwg's current and availible
pros: Serving municipality with my experoenced skill set snd leadership
cons: Ño overtime, lay-off cycled with drastic price with WCS Commodity

text: its a great place to work i wish im working there again. And very competitive wages and lots of benefits if you become a regular employee of the city
The City is an Excellent place to work especially for long term employment. Used to have a better pension plan structure and better retirement payout etc

amazing people who are supportive and helpful in achieving personal success, excellent work culture, management works with you rather than over you.over all an amazing place to work and set up a future.

I have been employed with The City of Calgary for over 11 years and have found them a very good employer with the opportunity to progress and also change career   The offer very competitive wages for a municipality and work/life balance is something they pride themselves on.  The City is a very sort after place to work in Calgary.   The team I work on is busy and high achieving, but we still have fun in our day to day tasks and going to work each day is always enjoyable.
cons: Union structure can sometimes be restrictive

text: Lots of support from the experienced members of the team. A learning, collaborative, and supportive environment. Emphasis on ensuring that employees are able to enjoy their lives outside of work.

Ok place to work Good pay Not stable No benefits until full time Need another job while working here as no guarantees of hours per week  Favouritism plays a role when covering shifts unfortunately
Out f all the places i have work the City of Calgary was by far the best. From the minute i walked in everyone was so welcoming and friendly. they where also there to to help you no matter what.

Overall my experiences working with the City of Calgary were positive and rewarding. A great place for advancement and encourage you to always upgrade your skill set with education options. Great work life balance
great place, passionate people, good structure, very busy, culture depends on the unit and the leadership, overall very good environment, good opportunities for movement.

A typical day at work: face to face processing of various payments for: admissions, program registrations, bookings and rentals as well as facilitate financial transactions, prepare bank deposits and complete cash reconciliations.Administrate: program registrations, facility bookings, fee assistance, employee fitness passes and personal training package purchasesRespond to customer inquiries, requests and complaints regarding Centre services.

I had a great few weeks volunteering with the City of Calgary helping run and organize events for summer day camps at Nose Hill Park. The program was smoothly run, and the other volunteers were friendly.

Very little in terms of out of work stuff going on in the office, but the office is relaxed and good to work at. Low pressure environmkent, typically get in and go about your work. Expected to get work done, but not pushed to work all the time, so breaks are expected.
For the most part it's a good place to work. You could do a lot worse. I'll remain as long as they'll have me. Will start you as seasonal employee and you can expect a layoff in late fall.

•	Worked during city-wide municipal vote for the 2026 Winter Olympics, Provincial Election, and the Federal Election.•	Helped organize community center voting stations, election advertisements, as well as assessing the votes and releasing the results at the end of the day•	Helped assist seniors and individuals with mobility restrictions
Steady employment with opportunities in the future. Excellent pension and benefits. Safety positive environment. Good place to develop new skills and learn.
All staff are hardworking, and put our customers first. Work/life balance is excellent.  Management build relationships with staff and easily approachable. Best job I've ever had.

The office environment is very fun, and expansive (can only speak for Seattle). It is a very challenging company due to the pace and ingenuity around every corner, which is awesome. If you apply yourself, you’ll go somewhere. Yes, office politics exist, but generally, it’s a meritocracy.”
Roads is Managed and maintained by a toxic work environment, fear of management and corporate Bullying throughout department. Human Resources department is completely complicit with the culture..
There are a lot of team event to help you know the organization well and familiarize you to the work. The team also gave me flexibility to work on what I proposed.

Even with the challenges related to the projects managed by City employees, the environment is light and very collaborative. It is really driven by the 4 C's : Collaboration, Character, Commitment and Competency.
good working place. high productivity. challenging projects. good culture. recommended to professionals, engineers and technicians. people work there are knowledgeable.
A rewarding experience with many career choices of a corporation with over 17,000 employees. Several unions, careers and levels for personal advancement.

As a volunteer, my responsibilities were to support the counselors in delivering programming to upwards of 30 campers. While I held a volunteer position at the time, I acquired the skills needed to apply for and enjoy a successful part-time career working with other non-profit camps in the Kananaskis.Trying to decide if the camp life is for you? Try volunteering first!
I worked for a day as a DRO for the provincial elections. The environment was fast paced and the co-workers were very helpful. If I get a chance, I would love to go back and work again.
Good place to work but the politics can ruin a guy if he can’t brush it off  The workers are awesome and do their best  Management is questionable to say the least

I always enjoyed going to work in the morning, I never had a bad day at work. The experiences I got to be involved in, really gave me great life experience. The employees within the workplace were like no other, they were always there to help and always fun to work with. The culture within the workplace is like nothing I have ever experienced, it felt like one big family.

The Waste and Recycling Services section is unfair and unequal to employees, showing blatant favouritism to some and a consistent history of antagonism and contempt for others. An employee can expect harassment and personal attacks by management as well as a toxic work environment. The job gave an overall feeling of "us" against "them" (being the city).
Enjoy a great career in multiple settings and roles as you can move around and do whatever you choose in many different fields.  When you work with the City of Calgary, you will be very pleased.
Job satisfaction depends on a variety of factors such as who your supervisor/superior is, who your coworkers are, the type of program you work in, and the budget of the program.

When you're at the bottom of the totem pole when working for the city, it takes YEARS to move up. I was stuck on the night shift for 7 years with no light at the end of the tunnel. I have young children and working nights became too much on my body and family. They have wonderful benefits and holiday/sick time and paid pretty good though!

You get to work with different individuals that either can help you progress or will throw you under the bus. I enjoyed meeting different types of customers. I enjoyed the different types of events that were done within the facility. You also had the opportunity to work outdoors in the summer. There was in-house training within the City. Courses that you could take to better yourself.
It was fun to work for the city, met good people. The pay was good and fair. I also learned lots of new things. Only thing that was bad was some of the management.

Stable secure job. Wages seem good at first, but deductions for all your benefits reduces take home pay in a big way. Good people overall, but troublemakers never get fired. Worked there 27 years. The pension is nice. Be aware, this is a sewage treatment plant! A very large sewage treatment plant.

The Parks Department is a large and diverse workplace within the City of Calgary, with many divisions working together to help create and more a more enjoyable experience with Calgary's green spaces.Everyday is a new challenge, which makes the job more challenging and rewarding.

This job is not fun, however it does keep you occupied. For a 60year old man, it is perfect. You have to be organized, if you don't you will be going back to the same house 4 times. You have to have a great personality to overcome negativity , People are usually nice to you. However you will meet the odd one. Great exercise.

Applied with 3000 people. 40 made the cut 2 years after. 4 months of very hard training. The worse time of my life. Discriminated against, harrassed, bullied, abused, dehumanized, ridiculed in front of every other coworker. Anyway, I believe it is a great job if you get on the right side of the bunch bullies.

My workplace culture is great where I get to learn and enjoy working with my co-workers. My work let me spend time with my family as well therefore my work life balance is good. My manager listens to my problems if I have any and provide me solutions as well.

The office environment is very fun, and expansive (can only speak for Seattle). It is a very challenging company due to the pace and ingenuity around every corner, which is awesome. If you apply yourself, you’ll go somewhere. Yes, office politics exist, but generally, it’s a meritocracy.”

I left the city due to personal reasons and mainly additional stress that I was facing that time. While I wanted to join back, with more experience and jollifications, I am not given an opportunity so for.

Working for the City was great. Many opportunities to apply in different business units from within. They offered wellness sessions from meditation, yoga, nutrition, gyms and riding bicycles by the river! Ever hear of a company doing that? The services offered to employees really blossomed over the years and the City is a great place to work.

Counted ballots and learned the whole election process, it was a great learning experience for a young kid like me, I would recommend it to anyone who wants to learn about the election process and see how things work in Calgary.
Hired to work on an ERP Implementation and continued to work there after the implementation to support the ERP system. Great people to work with in a relaxed environment.
I have been with the city for 17 years and wouldn't change a day of it.  The ability to learn new positions and the security of knowing I can provide for my family
City of Calgary is an excellent place to work, if you are ambitious and hard working this is a place to gain appreciation and visibility.I loved and enjoyed working at the City of Calgary.
Was the best place I've worked in a long time, my TEAM was amazing!!What more can I say The Bonny Brook Waste Water Treatment Plant was a GREAT place to work.

I enjoyed working at the City very much.  I received the job through Mark Staffing.  I worked for a couple of the Councillors during the summer of 2015 and I worked on Reception for the remaining time I was there.  Everyone was very nice and supportive.

The city of Calgary was a good summer job for a short period of time. But the work environment was bad at best. You have no ability to advance in the industry and no changes could be made to staff due to the union.
Flexible work environment, great coworkers, culture is ok. management is good, but not stable as most people are contract and waiting to be permanent,

City of CALGARY is a nice place to work. The people are helpful and friendly. There are always possibilities towards job advancement. If you work hard you will reap from your efforts. Communication between departments could be improved. I would recommend the City of CALGARY!
A continuous learning environment with the ability to advance easily. Peers are light-hearted but serious when needed. Kept busy by having different challenges daily
Enjoyable working with culturally diverse crew doing paint and fence repair for seniors who qualified for this City service. The pay at the time was minimum wage.
I strongly suggest to anyone to work for the city of Calgary because it’s relaxed and there’s a wide verity of work to be done and the benefits are ok and the pay is good

First of all my boss was the very best in terms of leadership and caring. As in most corporate environments there are colleagues who just don’t know how to get along with others and this decreases the value of your job. The pay and benefits are the great as is the work/life balance. The city is different in that City Counsellors and top brass pass down  orders and directives that are almost impossible for a manager to complete. The managers then look like the bad guys when passing directives to the average workers. Again this is the difficulty working in a corporate atmosphere. Otherwise the City takes care of their employees well, especially at the Fire Department.
It was very hands off and I was free to manage my own work days.  There was a lot of office politics though. The pay was fair and there was nice to have every 3rd Friday off.
Had lots of fun leading activities and interacting with children and collaborating with other staff.  It helped me learn how to time manage more efficiently.
Great place to work with a diverse culture and good leadership values. The organization values growth and development and supports mental health. The compensation is good.

This is a great career and employer but with cut backs and other outside influences looming it has become a very unknown and unstable future type workplace. Very stressful not knowing what is happening day to day and no potential to advance or increase income! After contract negotiations the workers were left to live with ZERO increases for 3 years while inflation and the cost of living in Calgary continuously skyrockets out of control! It's Impossible to survive or even buy a home on a single income for a ridiculous amount of work and health and safety concerns with no wage increases while a loaf of bread is $4.00 and higher ! Totally unacceptable from a city employer from my vast career experiences!

It has been a pleasure working for the city and serving citizens with the information they are looking for.  The management team is very supportive and helps understanding the procedures in a friendly manner. I am looking forward for full time position.

The office environment is very fun, and expansive (can only speak for Seattle). It is a very challenging company due to the pace and ingenuity around every corner, which is awesome. If you apply yourself, you’ll go somewhere. Yes, office politics exist, but generally, it’s a meritocracy.”
Awesome place, no complaints thus far. Pay and venerate great, hours are great and friendly environment. Only downfall is you get laid off the first year so you start from zero again after recall.

Great seasonal jobDays consisted of...-First Aid (when needed)-Statistics-Provide information to park visitors-Small scale maintenance-Park safety advocateas well as anything else required of me while on shift

Great place to work but very hard to secure a full time position. The call center staff is was always very nice and expressed a willingness to help the newbies. Managers were available and professional
The corporations among different team such as web server team, web service team, database team, security and development and support team are good. We have a scrum meeting every day.

Regular work in daytime never overtimeSupervisor is so nice and friendly,we respected each otherWorking at" The City" looks like stay at  a international familyI like to attend "Stampeded breakfast party" and "Christmas Party"Wish go back working the City again!!!

I decided to write a review but I am only giving them a one star to help bring their ratings to a more realistic level. They should be about maybe a three. This is one of those places if they do not like you and they want an excuse to get rid of you, then they will. I worked hard for them and they let me go. I don't hold grudges against them. This review is to just tell you to be very careful. Good luck
Great to work with.Wish the budget had not slashed my position. Felt appreciated and valued even as a contractor from day 1. Staff made me feel at home and the workplace was positive and intelligent.

Productive and very respectful place to workIt was a contract job thats why I left after completing my contract term.at Calgary Police Services very friendly and Respectful environment, Energetic Organisation. Love to work there.

A typical day at work: - abuse abuse abuseWhat I learned - NEVER work for the city of calgaryManagement - THEY are the ABUSERSWorkplace Culture - There is noneThe hardest part of the job - NOT walking outthe most enjoyable part of the job - absolutey zero
Great environment, good culture and ethics, great location, teams. ( I have to add 150 words to go to the next level with indeed, does not make sense )
Very chill, coworkers are super friendly and have a great atmosphere altogether. Working with them has taught me a lot about customer service, and I am very grateful for that.
Good experience for any age. Good skills, good people. Leadership was fun and enjoyable. Advancement opportunities. Able to make lifelong connections and relationships.

Under the city of Calgary's employment, I gained an amount of practical experience that I hope will aid in my future career. Working with children is always difficult but due to the organization and maturity of my coworkers the issues that came up were swiftly dealt with. I was given enough freedom to perform my duties and complete my program fully.

You're just a numberManagement is stuck in their own ways, have a more efficient idea? Don't bother. If it makes sense, they don't like youPolitics and different personalities and can become quite bs after awhile. Started off as a great place... That's where I'll end it

The work was great but management don’t have a clue on how to operate and deal with people always trying jack the personal around especially in winter don’t train the for the shortage of equipment operators always training more operators on loaders when they have tons but in graders which is shortage is the last to get trained on.
cons: No life and health balance they don’t care about that

text: Worked as an aquatics fitness instructor. Hourly pay was good, no benefits and no job security (contract work without a written contract so you could be replaced at any time). Taught morning classes on weekend; and evening classes during the week around another full time job (not at City). I was replaced permanently when I asked for a week off to visit family out of town and this ended up ending my employment with the City. No loyalty from employer even though I received Employee of the Month just 2 weeks prior and was awarded a Subway Samdwich gift card (that was never activated by the City) so I couldn’t even use it and when I asked for a replacement, all I got was runaround.
Work life balance was amazing here as was the compensation. Lots of opportunities to move around and move up. Job security and access to great benefits.
Worked with great people. Positive and challenging work environment.
cons: Part time because of union - hard to get additional hours

text: The Day start with the Free coffee.checking the ticketing queue and scheduling the tickets. Calling the end users.  Discussing with the senior team mates for possible solutions
able to gain experience and move through different experience.  multiple online learning courses that enhance your employment experience. For someone who is driven, it is a great place to work.

The office environment is very fun, and expansive (can only speak for Seattle). It is a very challenging company due to the pace and ingenuity around every corner, which is awesome. If you apply yourself, you’ll go somewhere. Yes, office politics exist, but generally, it’s a meritocracy.”

A typical day at work in The City of Calgary is wonderful because there you are treated with dignity. Everybody share values and are committed to do their best. That's why The City of Calgary is a great place to work.

Personally the best job I have had to date. This is a perfect place to learn new skills and become part of a life long community. The most enjoyable part of this job is being part of recreation and creating a safe and fun environment for children, youth and adults. The hardest part of this job is terminating your position after being part of this lovely community. This job is for people who work hard, have a passion for kids and aquatics, are open to learning and growing as a individual.

The best part about the City - work life balance. With 7.75 hours a day, you get to take every alternate Fridays off. Work culture is very self motivated i.e. if you are motivated enough to get something done then you take the initiative to get it done without the possibility of extra pay. As with every other job there are pluses and minuses. Talk to as many people as you can and create your own opinion about working for the City.
pros: Great work security and work life balance

text: A bit bureaucratic at timesA bit hierarchal Interesting workManagement lead by exampleProcess could be refined for quicker turnaround Colleagues are nice

The City of Calgary is a very good government to work for. They pay well, offer great work-life balance, solid benefits, pension plan. Managers lead by example, are strong communicators. Most employees work there in order to retire, not for the challenge or opportunity to grow, and are not very ambitious

Excellent colleagues, environments, open to new ways of doing things and they care about their staff improving and gaining experience as well as training. The culture is diverse. The clients are very demanding on the operations side of things and they can be the worst part of the job.
pros: Exposure and experience to different things
cons: Client expectations are difficult to manage, promotions are not that easy to come by

text: Really enjoyed my time that day and as am retired now can work  days prior to election and hours as required. Willing to train for any position available. I am experienced in pressure situations and love the challenge.

I took a 6 month contract at the City of Calgary with the hopes of getting a full time position. Unfortunately there were funding cut backs and my position was not extended. The most frustrating part of working for the City is room for advancement. I applied for several jobs that I had all of the qualifications for, but never even received one interview. This was due to seniority within the union at the City.

Inclusive and positive work environment. A typical day at work for me would be to arrive at 8:09 and work on work that has been assigned to me throughout the day. Some of the work I do is research on projects, which I do enjoy.

I enjoyed working for the Calgary Fire Department for 25 years. I retired as a Captain in charge of a firehall with men and equipment to serve the citizens of Calgary.Learned many skills in firefighting, saving lives and protecting property and the environment.The hardest part was dealing with people injured and how their lives were affected. The most enjoyable part was seeing how happy people were when we helped them

Would be a great place to work if you start young and don't mind working your way up the hierarchy. Until you reach seniority you can expect to be put on any rout or traded to any department or given any job for many years. I was told by other employees the best way to succeed there is to do exactly as you're told but don't do any extra because no one will notice or care if they do. That was very good advice.
pros: good pay and benifits, schedual rotation gives you 4 days off in a row, community clean ups were fun
cons: union culture hard to get used to, some sketchy people work there

text: Everything is great about working for the City of Calgary Transit department except for the daily 12 hour split shifts, the monotony of the work, the hazards of traffic, and the threat of assault from hostile customers. It requires great dedication, collaboration with other operators to accommodate shift changes, ability to deal with difficult customers and to operate a bus and stay on schedule, safely and with courtesy at all times, on various routes, sometimes more than two or three different routes per day, regardless of conditions of the roadway and the customer, including drunken and belligerent customers. Other than all that, it pays very well, has great medical benefits, a good pension, union support, and free uniform including shoes, socks, winter coat and gloves.
cons: High stress, daily 12 hour split shifts

text: The all successful business understand how important productivity is in a work environment .an employees productivity  can help the company in utilize

Top heavy management, too many managers who micro manager to few union staff. Management are arrogant and vile. Lots of bullying and intimidation. To cut property taxes, cut management. Those who do the work are union people. MME's do nothing except micro manage.
I worked here for years and have nothing bad too say except they dont treat you well if you have personal issues and need time off and come back. They bullied me out of the company

i worked for parks out of high school its a very good place to get your foot in the door with the city of Calgary being seasonal for some people works but at the time it didn't for me but luckily there is lots of things to do for them

I've had a few jobs with the City of Calgary. There are many different walks of life that work there which is wonderful but can also be challenging. There are a lot of expectations with very little support at times, and I found that there were some managers that didn't have the skills to be there. Overall, good starting point for young adults to integrate into the working world, but not a long time career choice
Some great people work here but there is no accountability for management. There is poor communication among teams and there is a genuine fear for people's jobs. Would not recommend working here.
Nothing very fascinating but people are nice. Still stick with old technology. They try to grow but things are slow. Good benifits and salary. Free parking at some locations is good.
Good place to work, great people. I have worked in several business units across the organization. Each time I work in a new business unit I am pleased with the welcome I recieve.

They treat you like a person, not an employee. That’s reflected in the benefits and how management approaches employees, no yelling and screaming about challenges, just collaboration and ideas. The office environment is very fun, and expansive (can only speak for Seattle). It is a very challenging company due to the pace and ingenuity around every corner, which is awesome. If you apply yourself, you’ll go somewhere. Yes, office politics exist, but generally, it’s a meritocracy.”
Very fast paced position dealing with children between the age of 3-14(typically). Good teamwork is required and supervision is helpful to improve the day camps and sports camps.

Great summer internship, you get to meet a lot of other students, the work load and responsibilities are quite fair. The City offers a really good mentorship program where you can be matched with a mentor that can help your career.
Great people to work with, awesome learning and advancement opportunities.  Possible education assistance.  Great benefits and hours of work.  Very flexible.
Interesting and complex work, good people and lots of diverse jobs. Leadership is hit or miss depending on the department and division you are in. Great pay and benefits
This was a summer student position; however, I was given a ton of support in pursuing matters I was interested in. I had the best managers imaginable.

Loved working for the city of Calgary but I would like to work closer to home . Loved interacting with customers and employees that I work with We were tonight’s split shifts early mornings drove eight hours a day had to deal with situations of bad weather and good weather Train to drive an Airbrake vehicle
cons: A lot of assaults on bus drivers

text: Everyday I am thankful that I was hired by The City of Calgary.  They treat you always with dignity and respect and it was the first legal position I have had in 26 years that I feel like a valued member of a team.
This is a great place for work life balance. Management seems to be lacking communication and leadership. Career opportunities are largely based upon education and not skill.
Good working environment and opportunity for advancement.Location is advantageous, good accessibility. Parking is also available. Lunch room is avaialble

Very fun,productive and supporting work environment. So far it was my favorite place to work. I learned a whole lot of new things with all the training sessions that i feel like ill definitely use in the future.
Great place to work at without many of the perks that come with a job in the private sector, such as Christmas parties. Good internal training program.
they where very understanding with the work hours and they had great management and I loved the shoes there highly recommend working there because of the friendly attitude and welcoming atmosphere

I worked there for 27 years and enjoyed every day of it. I was given opportunities  to learn new skills and get job advancement . I found the management was fair and we all had equal opportunity for positions as they became available.
Working with children can be stressful, and the management does not always seem to know what they are doing, but the coworkers are nice and it's good to have an outside job

Typical day at work was professional, yet casual.  Safety and Diversity in the Workplace is strongly promoted.  There was no dress code and in a professional environment I was allowed to take breaks when desired.  There was no time keeper and as long as I was productive my work ethic was never questioned.  My team leader was very knowledgeable and did not micro manage our department.  Every one in my group was approachable and there was no requirement to follow a chain of command even though we have senior positions and coordinators.  When I had ideas or a desire to take on new tasks, I would usually be granted my request if I could provide a use case and it did not impact the department.  I was able to learn new skills by taking the initiative and approaching my team leader.  The hardest part of the job was to work with others that I would deem unproductive.  These type of workers are protected by the union and it is very difficult for management to take action.  Therefore, all you can do is maintain a positive attitude and think of your contributions and not the lack of others.  Thank goodness 99% of City of Calgary employees are respectful hard working individuals.  I enjoyed coffee breaks with co-workers, organized city events, the freedom of my position, the ability to work four days a week, the option to work two days from home, and lots more.
pros: Pension, flexible work hours, telework option, very competitive wages, compressed work week, apply/work in temporary City positions while retaining your base position.

text: Great place to work, treat you like people. Excellent work climate. wish all companies treated employees this way. One draw back, some positions traditionally held by women are not unionized and therefore you get treated and paid way way less.

great way to get a farmers tan. early mornings and beautiful grounds.lots of lazy people looking to do the bare minimum. the best part of the job was a job well done. the worst part of the job was doing other workers jobs over because they didnt do it right the first time
cons: working in all kinds of weather

text: it was a definite learning experience where I strengthened my role of leadership. I was making no money because it was volunteering but I received a few free lunches and had some great times
Overall day to day work is fairly easy-going. Great place to grow and learn different skills. Management and workplace culture is okay, depends on your department.
I got to learn a lot about interactions with others throught the job, i was a volunteer so i didn't get paid but I still got rewarded for my hardwork at the end of it.

They treat you like a person, not an employee. That’s reflected in the benefits and how management approaches employees, no yelling and screaming about challenges, just collaboration and ideas. The office environment is very fun, and expansive (can only speak for Seattle). It is a very challenging company due to the pace and ingenuity around every corner, which is awesome. If you apply yourself, you’ll go somewhere. Yes, office politics exist, but generally, it’s a meritocracy.”
So much fun working with the city. Learn everyday new things, always expecting to help people with what they need, and at the end of the day, you feel so comfortable after getting your job done.

This was a temporary position to help organize voter ballots for Calgary's 2017 Municipal Election. I enjoyed the work environment immensely, everyone was a good team player to one-another to get everything done and it was an experience I will not forget any time soon.
Excellent place to learn skills gain customer service and technical experience,  Hours are reasonable and people are fantastic, very family friendly environment.
I got hired on as a temporary full-time employee, with a two-year probationary period. Wanted to make career out of it, but got laid off  due to budget cuts one week before I became permanent.

Got to pick which days I wanted to work with my job in the recreation department, which meant I could choose hours that worked with my schedule. Opportunity for pay raises annually with performance reviews (at least in the area that I was in) and great people to work alongside with.
pros: opportunity for pay raises and awesome work environment

text: A typical day of work is to keep busy and time go by fast. I have had experience that i do not know before. Also, the Management is nice , they look after you very good and friendly workplace. The hardest part of the jobs is remove the snow and your sweeper is broken. For me, the most enjoyable part of the job is driving on cops's cars.
working in a team we created game taught kids to play. We did this for the summer throughout the city,  went on field trips and educational actives included.
Seasonal employees do not get to contribute to their pension. minimum two years of working seasonally before you are able to work full time. That was very upsetting for the 24 new hires.

Although on paper, each duty/job is very clear, the actual expectations of each job is very unpredictable. Each day is a new surprise with what you are expected to do and often times you are left on your own to figure out how to reach the end goals.
Most enjoyed working with the developmental department assisting with the implementation of new software for the occupational hazard and incident reporting.
pros: Great hours, calm work environment and good salary

text: Excellent place to work.  I thoroughly enjoyed my internship at the City of Calgary and was amazed at how nice everyone was.  It is no wonder that people rarely leave once they are in at the city.

Working for Recreation in the City of Calgary was fun for a while, but did not work for me as an individual. I worked one or two 3-4 hour shifts a week. The pay was fair and the environment was positive and helpful. I just didn't feel the job was right for me, and I needed more working hours from my part time job.  I love the kids I got to work with, though the parents were sometimes stressful. Overall it was a positive experience.
As a sub-contractor, opportunity for advancement is minimal. You do not get all the tools to perform your job efficiently and receive pressure on things out of your control.

I worked for parks since 1996 and now worst season.  The city hires contracting out for parks and roads. Normally. Started work on April 1st until November Remembrance Day long weekend. April 1st to November 10th. Now the city changed to April 15th to October 10th.I am seasonal park labourer and truck driver. I was hard worker, maintenance, litter pick, laying on the sods, playround renovation,  painting, baseball diamonds grooming, inspect bleachers and more.  Our health benefits are excellent.  I do not recommended anyone to apply for parks due to corruption.
cons: needs to improve and needs new manager.

text: - little communication- poor performers protected- good workers leave - poor management- minimal recognition of accomplishments- no annual review of job performance - no peer job performances- reports to HR go no-where- annual work plan rarely reviewed, or completed
This was a really fun place to work while in school. Flexible hours and good pay. Would love to go back one day. There were many wonderful people I worked with.
Provides great work/life balance. Under new financial restraints, less staff is hired with growing infrastructure which does make it tough to manage, I was proud to work here for many years (15).

311 is front line for all business units within the City of Calgary. Calls range from property tax to sewer backup and bylaw complaints. The calls can be both frustrating and fulfilling. As tough as the job is, the people working there are great and the management allows a lot of flexibility with scheduling and understands how mentally trying it can be sometimes. I appreciate the 4 day work week, the pay and management.

very  early mornings and set up for day, busy all day sometimes stressful, most customers are quite pleasent and enjoy coming there. sometimes heavy lifting but employees are willing to work together to get things done
great organization, not much job security in current position, very little ability for job advancement due to constant hiring freezes. certain job codes not worth being employed for.

pay was great, but the city would keep around totally useless workers. Its impossible to get rid of a bad employee benefits were fantastic pay was great

Management of the Parks and Recreation branch in the City of Calgary is accommodating and fair. In my position as a Recreation Leader, I was tasked with creating weekly scheduled activities for kids aged 6-12 and leading them. As the face of the organization, I had to have excellent communication skills so that parents are able to trust leaders, and are aware of how their children are doing at camp.

The City of Calgary was an equal opportunity employer. It provides good entry level positions, but advancement is difficult. It is a wonderful place to gain work experience. There are also frequent trainings available to city employees and I'd recommend taking advantage of those.
pros: Great benefits, job security, training opportunities
cons: Difficult to advance, very low pay for entry level positions

text: Good company, if you desire advancement they will be willing to promote from within. They are great for advancement, learning new skills, and job security.
A very nice to work with job security.  Good work/life balance and excellent opportunities for career development.  Fast paced most of the time subject to economic factors.
pros: Morning and Afternoon breaks and one Friday off every month
cons: Salary a bit lower than private sector

text: Good experience and enjoyed my tenure.Focus on the company and your individual experience while employed thereProvide reasons for why you liked or disliked working at the companyEnsure any facts you include in your review are true and accurate

On a typical day at work I would answer anywhere between 60-80 calls. I learned how to work with 29 different business units. Management was great with support. Hardest part of the jobs was sometimes having to sent service request to other departments that take time to adhere to. Fulfilling customer requests and being able to help them out.

Daily challenges safely transporting people under a variety of conditions that can change in an instant. Always nice at the end to be told what a great job you had done by the customers, yet never knowing what any particular day will bring your way!
The only thing is it's hard work and the schedule is not definite and management is a little unorganized but other then that it's great people, rewarding work and a satisfactory part time job.
Best manager I've been with, the working environment and co-workers are very laid back, lot's of opportunities to transfer between departments and lots of opportunities to grow.
The work environment allowed a wide scope of professional practice. A friendly environment where coworkers were willing to share their experience and knowledge.

You always hear about how working for the city is a life long career and how the benefits are so great but it really was not that great. City hires most people on contracts for years and before you become permanent they lay you off so they aren't stuck with you. They hire Sait students with big promises and never follow thru. The pay is really good and its a pretty relax environment generally but then once in a while management would drop the hammer on the team leads, who in turn drop the hammer on foreman, who in turn take it out on you for absolutely nothing.  The guys doing the hiring and firing don't know who you are and have never seen you do a day of work. so if you do good work everyday for years and have a couple of mistakes in a row management will wash their hands with you.  the facilities are all dated, a lot of old school mentality with guys just working to retire in the next few years and don't really care about the job anymore.
Amazing management, work life balance, great corporate culture, great pay rate , value of employees , flexibility , and employees are always encouraged to learn more and more

Working for the City of Calgary has the benefit of being part of a  union which in turn leads to certain pros and cons. Good pay and benefits are both nice to have however overtime is hard to come by and the structure of the Aquatics hierarchy make advancement hard to come by. The majority of the job is closer to public relations and teaching rather than life guarding itself.

Some good, some bad.  The presence of a union ensures that anyone with a poor attitude or a lackluster work ethic stays on for years, effectively poisoning positive spirits.  Salary is way above industry average, and most people are great to work with. On the plus side, I was blessed with an excellent boss who provided me with whatever I needed and even provided support on her days off! Very difficult to get a full-time, permanent position here, and I'm not sure I'd want one.  They can move you, change your position and you have no say over what they've decided.
I loved my years working for Calgary Transit.  Felt respected and valued.  A great opportunity to work with other professional drivers and provide  customer service.

Management is poorly trained and long time staff are very nasty.  Probably a form of PTSD or Compassion Fatigue but not a very pleasant atmosphere to work in.   The job itself, 911, is stressful but very rewarding.
Early safety meetings followed by vehicle maintenance . Review of public safety notifications. Emergency responses as called upon. Training in theory and practical application.
cons: stressful situations of life and death

text: Got to work with good people on interesting projects. They are committed to developing staff, doing solid work and place high value on customer service.

People are pleasant enough and there is a fair amount of collaboration. There are advancement opportunities but sometimes subject to union rules. There are opportunities to move to other positions and get trained on other skills. Pay is great. But manager tends to micromanage things. The political / unionized environment means one has to be careful what one says around people so as not to raise any red flags.
cons: unionized environment, hard to get in

Enjoy the dynamic everyone was productive and easy going as well as professional. Made some great friends in the time I was there, wish I could have accepted the positions permanently.
cons: they don't hire from external temp agencies

text: very great place to work especially for constructiongreat pay and benefits. vacation timeawesome co workers and bosseshelped me learn about direction
great place to work,  WAY TOO MANY MANAGEMENT due to economy,  budget cuts equals Group Layoffs  aside from that,  the city is a fair place to work,   :)
pros: great work and home life balance
cons: forever critzied for being a lazy city employee

text: No day is the same with this type of job, as different types of people come in every day. A good place to meet new people. New challenges every day that requires time and patience.

great place to work, management great. the pay is the only down fall,,,low money no benefits. best part is meeting lots of people. i drive golf cart and sell beer, wine coolers, chips sandwiches and choc bars. 8-9 hr days
cons: low pay not allowed to accept tips

text: I've been with the City for 10 years. It has been a good experience and I've been able to advance my Career very well.My shift is good now. My life and time with my child is very good.The job has been a rewarding experience.
Very respectful for the most part ,  reasonable wages ,  good benefits , good balance of work/life . good relations ship between front line workers and management.

I worked as a census taker for 2017 and found this job is fun to have. I can work with and rearrange my own schedule in order to meet the deadline. Going door to door to collect information allowed me to meet and talk to different people. It also allows me to earn some income while doing my daily walk.

Positive part about this job is being able to create a bond with new people. Learning new and old things. Being apart of someone's life, and making a difference or not and helping someone through a difficult time.  I would like to work part time with an opportunity to work more if needed.Being honest .. it has been a long time since I have applied for a job. I would love the opportunity to see where I can go. ThankyouGillian

I have enjoyed working with the City as it has afforded me a good balance between my work and personal life. However, the evangelized values of Character, Competence, Commitment and Collaboration are, sadly, inconsistently practiced across the departments.

typical day consists of morning meetings with the foreman for the current days scheduling and tasks, different groups perform different tasks,  we were responsible for planting flowers in city parks while maintaining them.
great place to work where the training never stops. Always room for advancement, and the benefits are pretty nice too. everyone there is friendly and will advise you on the do's an don'ts .

I was under the Facility Management. Facility management is currently building five (5) Recreational Facilities in the City of Calgary. 1 project worth over 100M and it is almost  in completion this year. The other 4 projects have a budget of over 450M. These 4 projects will be completed within 2 years.

I enjoyed all aspects of this job. Everyone was approachable. The work was done at a medium pace and we all learned alot about our area (yard work). We were also given classes on minor repairs and painting. Once a month we had a guest speaker who talked on various life skills (budgeting to healthcare).
cons: The job was not for everyone.

text: Though working with the city was a wonderful oppurtunity it provided very little job security for part-time employees and they never gave you a definitive answer as to whether or not they would be giving you a job again next season.  There was never a point in time that i did not have a minimum of 3 foreman controlling a maximum of 12 people.  I never actually figured out what they did during a day aside from call the crews for updates and meetings.  All i can say is that i was blessed to be able to work with the city for the time i did but they really need to revise the ammount of management there.
cons: confusing/vague and often contradicting orders from management

text: Long simple days working with young children during the summer. helped the camp leaders run games and activities for the children. Friendly fun environment.

UUUUUM I show up to the skatepark unlock it, sign kids in, ensure that they are wearing helmets. maybe teach the occasional skate lesson. But mostly just skateboard all day. what more can I say. Awesome summer job
cons: you get cooked in the sun

text: Conducted extensive research on E-learning options and patiently consulted with different E-learning specialists. Designed interactive E-learning demos by using Adobe Captivate 8 and other software tools. Successfully gave several formal presentations about my E-learning project to team members and stakeholders inregular meetings. Carefully prepared and compiled reports on recommendations.

I was one of hundreds of administrative support professionals in a department caught in a fiscal restraint policy of The City of Calgary.  My fellow support staff, many who had been in service to the City for 20+ years, and myself suddenly found ourselves bereft of employment, representation - and support - as we watched our department disappear and our services outsourced.

its a good place to work due to the kind of leaders I have I know some people don't have this to say but I am grateful for the kind of leadership I have

My job had me moving around a lot. From working as a helper on a chemical truck. Going to different fire halls. And pickup up chemicals and returning to base. Everyone has each others back. When one person had an off day. The rest of us would pick up the slack. Like most outside jobs Weather was always the down side of the job.But Formans   always  came to the rescue. Great job never wanted to leave. cut back with the city.Lots of jobs lost in waste management/roads/parks this past year.

As a Service Lane Attendant you learn how to work as a team. It is a very fast paced work environment, but you must always work safe at all times. We do various campaigns on the trains every week, which means we may lift seats and clear out garbage underneath or we may clean the light fixtures in the U2 vehicles. This is difficult physical work but we get the job complete. My favourite part of the job is getting the opportunity to drive and park the trains.

The City of Calgary provides a stable work environment.  Key to longevity in this work is consistency.  Reliable workers stay longer and go further. At times there are inconsistencies between policy and job demands.  This is common when those responsible for policy are not on the front line.   Friendly atmosphere in the department I worked
cons: Beauracracy. Top heavy. Different departments determine your long term expectations.

text: It was a great place to work at. great management and good co-workers. learned a lot about traffic engineering and traffic management center. Also I met a lot of great people
Good company to work for. Have good work culture. Very much everyone cooperative and helpful, and overall good place to work. The most enjoyable part of my job, is looking forward to go to work.

The building that I worked in had a fantastic gym facility that was accessible year round. The fee was very reasonable and there was also a fitness instructor available for tips and suggestions on my fitness goal.

I was only there for a summer position, but I felt I learned a decent amount from working there. I would not call my time with them exceptional in any particular way, but the overall experience was a positive one and I would definitely work there again if given the opportunity.
pros: Nothing horrible, fair wage, solid management
cons: Nothing amazing, felt my being there wasn't really noticed

text: It's a good place to work. Great benefits and great people. It was nice to see all the beautiful parks we have in Calgary.Every day was different and interesting .You are always busy and on the go. The days fly by and so does the season
Job and the people I work with are great. I wouldn't say that about the management and their treatment of the operators. The hours make traveling to work much easier in the busy Calgary traffic.
work well with others, able to multi-task,able to follow directions accurately, excellent customer care assistance, I am a quick learner.

The City gave me the opportunity to grow in my professional procurement experience. It exposed me to great projects that have a positive impact on the lives of many Calgarians. I highly recommend the city.
It was temporary assignment for a short period of a week only. Team members were very supportive. I wish I would have been worked for a long time with this company.

Work at the call centre can be hectic at times when call volumes are high but the pay is very good for customer service work and the benefits are excellent. The environment is very supportive thanks to management and it is truly like working with a close-knit family. You are left to make your own decisions and you are fully supported in doing that. Unfortunately, I had to move on after a limited term ended so I do wish there was more room for advancement/job security but other than that, I would highly recommend working at The City of Calgary.
pros: Great management, great benefits, good work environment
cons: Hectic pace during periods of high call volumes.

text: The City of Calgary was professional and upheld a high quality standards which in turn produced positive results. The workload was well spread throughout the employees and management was very accommodating if help was needed.
pros: Benefits, accommodating atmosphere, no overtime necessary

text: The City of Calgary of IT shop is one of the best to work. The staff are very knowledgeable, professional and innovative. Leadership provides great direction and have a solid plan on how to provide a very high quality of service to the citizens of Calgary.
Opportunity to participate in change and innovation. Work culture strenghthen and supported by the leadership team. Learning and development opportunities available.

I worked in an area for several years.   This year the Citychanged all the areas and crews. They are also subcontracting a lot of the Parks operations.My job will likely be phased out in the next couple of years. I enjoy working with plants and growing.   I supervised crews and worked right along with them to achieve success. I also operate a small home business greenhouse and have achieved success with my endeavours.
pros: Enjoyed the area I was working in
cons: No room for advancement or getting a full time position

text: The City of Calgary Swim Instructor position is a fun, flexible and empowering job. Instructors get to work with kids, adults and seniors in a linear progressive program that branches of as swimming ability improves.

I have enjoyed basically everything about my current job with the City. I like my co-workers and all of my bosses, and especially the kids. I've learned a lot about dealing with parents/customers and how to try and settle conflicts. I like everything about my job, its just not enough hours for me currently.
